14//***************************************************************************************
15// PRIVATE/OPAQUE STRUCTURES ----- DO NOT MODIFY! THINGS WILL BREAK!
16//***************************************************************************************
17
18// Private Struct Definitions for Hash State Contexts
19struct cryptx_priv_hash_sha256_state {
20 uint8_t data[64];
21 uint8_t datalen;
22 uint8_t bitlen[8];
23 uint32_t state[8];
24};
25typedef union {
26 struct cryptx_priv_hash_sha256_state sha256;
27} cryptx_hash_private_h;
28
29// Private Struct Definitions for HMAC State Contexts
30struct cryptx_priv_hmac_sha256_state {
31 uint8_t ipad[64];
32 uint8_t opad[64];
33 uint8_t data[64];
34 uint8_t datalen;
35 uint8_t bitlen[8];
36 uint32_t state[8];
37};
38typedef union {
39 struct cryptx_priv_hmac_sha256_state sha256;
40} cryptx_hmac_private_h;
41
42struct cryptx_aes_cbc_state { uint8_t padding_mode; };
43struct cryptx_aes_ctr_state {
44 uint8_t counter_pos_start; uint8_t counter_len;
45 uint8_t last_block_stop; uint8_t last_block[16]; };
46struct cryptx_aes_gcm_state {
47 uint8_t last_block_stop; uint8_t last_block[16];
48 uint8_t ghash_key[16];
49 uint8_t aad_cache[16]; uint8_t auth_tag[16]; uint8_t auth_j0[16];
50 uint8_t aad_cache_len; size_t aad_len; size_t ct_len;
51 uint8_t gcm_op;
52};
53
54typedef union {
55 struct cryptx_aes_gcm_state gcm;
56 struct cryptx_aes_cbc_state ctr;
57 struct cryptx_aes_ctr_state cbc;
58} cryptx_aes_private_h;

60//***************************************************************************************
61// HASHING
62//***************************************************************************************
65struct cryptx_hash_ctx {
66 bool (*init)(void* ctx);
67 void (*update)(void* ctx, const void* data, size_t len);
68 void (*digest)(void* ctx, void* output);
69 uint8_t digest_len;
70 cryptx_hash_private_h metadata;
71};
72
73enum cryptx_hash_algorithms {
74 SHA256,
75};
76
77/******************************************************
78 * @brief Initializes a hash-state context for a specific hash algorithm.
79 * @param[in] context Pointer to a hash-state context.
80 * @param[in] hash_alg The numeric ID of the hashing algorithm to use. See @b cryptx_hash_algorithms.
81 * @return @b true if hash initialization succeeded, @b false if failed.
82 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
83 */
84bool cryptx_hash_init(struct cryptx_hash_ctx* context, uint8_t hash_alg);
85
86/******************************************************
87 * @brief Updates the hash-state for a given block of data.
88 * @param[in] context Pointer to a hash-state context.
89 * @param[in] data Pointer to a block of data to hash..
90 * @param[in] len Size of the @b data to hash.
91 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
92 * @warning Calling this on a context that has not been initialized may have
93 * unpredictable results.
94 */
95void cryptx_hash_update(struct cryptx_hash_ctx* context, const void* data, size_t len);
96
97/******************************************************
98 * @brief Output digest for current hash-state (preserves state).
99 * @param[in] context Pointer to a hash-state context.
100 * @param[out] digest Pointer to a buffer to write digest to.
101 * @note @b digest must be at large enough to hold the hash digest.
102 * You can retrieve the necessary size by accessing the @b digest_len
103 * member of an initialized @b cryptx_hash_ctx.
104 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
105 * @warning Calling this on a context that has not been initialized may have
106 * unpredictable results.
107 */
108void cryptx_hash_digest(struct cryptx_hash_ctx* context, void* digest);
109
110/******************************************************
111 * @brief Computes a digest of arbitrary length for a given block of data.
112 * @param[in] data Pointer to data to hash.
113 * @param[in] datalen Size of @b data to hash.
114 * @param[out] outbuf Pointer to buffer to write digest to.
115 * @param[in] outlen Number of bytes to write to @b outbuf.
116 * @param[in] hash_alg The numeric ID of the hashing algorithm to use. See @b cryptx_hash_algorithms.
117 * @note @b outbuf must be at least @b outlen bytes large.
118 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
119 */
120void cryptx_hash_mgf1(const void* data,
121 size_t datalen,
122 void* outbuf,
123 size_t outlen,
124 uint8_t hash_alg);
125

127//***************************************************************************************
128// HASH-BASED MESSAGE AUTHENTICATION CODE (HMAC)
129//***************************************************************************************
132struct cryptx_hmac_ctx {
133 bool (*init)(void* ctx, const void* key, size_t keylen);
134 void (*update)(void* ctx, const void* data, size_t len);
135 void (*digest)(void* ctx, void* output);
136 uint8_t digest_len;
137 cryptx_hmac_private_h metadata;
138};
139
140/******************************************************
141 * @brief Initializes an HMAC-state context for a specific hash algorithm.
142 * @param[in] context Pointer to an HMAC-state context.
143 * @param[in] key Pointer to a key used to initialize the HMAC state.
144 * @param[in] keylen Length of the @b key.
145 * @param[in] hash_alg The numeric ID of the hashing algorithm to use. See @b cryptx_hash_algorithms.
146 * @return @b true if initialized succeeded, @b false if failed.
147 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
148 */
149bool cryptx_hmac_init(struct cryptx_hmac_ctx* context,
150 const void* key, size_t keylen,
151 uint8_t hash_alg);
152
153/******************************************************
154 * @brief Updates the hash-state for a given block of data.
155 * @param[in] context Pointer to an HMAC-state context.
156 * @param[in] data Pointer to a block of data to hash..
157 * @param[in] len Size of the @b data to hash.
158 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
159 * @warning Calling this on a context that has not been initialized may have
160 * unpredictable results.
161 */
162void cryptx_hmac_update(struct cryptx_hmac_ctx* context, const void* data, size_t len);
163
164/******************************************************
165 * @brief Output digest for current HMAC-state (preserves state).
166 * @param[in] context Pointer to an HMAC-state context.
167 * @param[out] digest Pointer to a buffer to write digest to.
168 * @note @b digest must be at large enough to hold the hash digest.
169 * You can retrieve the necessary size by accessing the @b digest_len
170 * member of an initialized @b cryptx_hmac_ctx.
171 * @note Uses 516 bytes of fastMem starting at 0xE30800.
172 * @warning Calling this on a context that has not been initialized may have
173 * unpredictable results.
174 */
175void cryptx_hmac_digest(struct cryptx_hmac_ctx* context, void* output);

178//***************************************************************************************
179// PASSWORD-BASED KEY DERIVATION FUNCTION 2 (PBKDF2)
180//***************************************************************************************
183/******************************************************
184 * @brief Derives a key from a password, salt, and round count.
185 * @param[in] password Pointer to a string containing the password.
186 * @param[in] passlen Byte length of the password.
187 * @param[in] salt A psuedo-random string to use in each round of key derivation.
188 * @param[in] saltlen Byte length of the salt.
189 * @param[in] rounds The number of times to iterate the HMAC function per block of @b keylen.
190 * @param[out] key Pointer to buffer to write key to.
191 * @param[in] keylen Length of @b key to generate.
192 * @param[in] hash_alg The numeric ID of the hashing algorithm to use. See @b cryptx_hash_algorithms.
193 * @note NIST recommends a salt of at least 128 bits (16 bytes).
194 * @note @b rounds is used to increase the cost (computational time) of generating a key. What makes password-
195 * hashing algorithms secure is the time needed to generate a rainbow table attack against it. More rounds means
196 * a more secure key, but more time spent generating it. Current cryptography standards recommend thousands of
197 * rounds but that may not be feasible on the CE.
198 */
199void cryptx_hmac_pbkdf2(const char* password,
200 size_t passlen,
201 const void* salt,
202 size_t saltlen,
203 uint8_t* key,
204 size_t keylen,
205 size_t rounds,
206 uint8_t hash_alg);
207
208
209//***************************************************************************************
210// DIGEST OPERATIONS
211//***************************************************************************************
214/******************************************************
215 * @brief Convert a digest to its hexstring representation.
216 * @param[in] digest Pointer to a buffer or digest.
217 * @param[in] len Byte length of @b digest.
218 * @param[out] hexstr Buffer to write the output hex string to.
219 * @note @b hexstr must be at least twice @b len +1 bytes large.
220 */
221bool cryptx_digest_tostring(const void* digest, size_t len, uint8_t* hexstr);
222
223/******************************************************
224 * @brief Compare two digests or buffers.
225 * @param[in] digest1 Pointer to first buffer to compare.
226 * @param[in] digest2 Pointer to second buffer to compare.
227 * @param[in] len Number of bytes to compare.
228 * @return @b true if the buffers are equal, @b false if not equal.
229 * @note This is a constant-time implementation.
230 */
231bool cryptx_digest_compare(const void* digest1, const void* digest2, size_t len);

234//***************************************************************************************
235// CRYPTOGRAPHICALLY-SECURE RANDOM NUMBER GENERATION
236//***************************************************************************************
239/******************************************************
240 * @brief Initializes the (HW)RNG.
241 * @returns @b true on success, @b false on failure.
242 * @note If you forget to call this function, utilizing the RNG's other functions will self-initialize the RNG.
243 */
244bool cryptx_csrand_init(void);
245
246/******************************************************
247 * @brief Returns a securely psuedo-random 32-bit integer
248 * @returns A securely psuedo-random 32-bit integer.
249 */
250uint32_t cryptx_csrand_get(void);
251
252/******************************************************
253 * @brief Fills a buffer with securely pseduo-random bytes
254 * @param[in] buffer Pointer to a buffer to fill with random bytes.
255 * @param[in] size Size of the buffer to fill.
256 * @returns @b true on success, @b false on failure.
257 * @returns @b buffer filled to size.
258 */
259bool cryptx_csrand_fill(void* buffer, size_t size);

262//***************************************************************************************
263// ADVANCED ENCRYPTION STANDARD (AES) ENCRYPTION
264//***************************************************************************************
267struct cryptx_aes_ctx {
268 uint24_t keysize;
269 uint32_t round_keys[60];
270 uint8_t iv[16];
271 uint8_t ciphermode;
272 uint8_t op_assoc;
273 cryptx_aes_private_h metadata;
274};
275
276enum cryptx_aes_cipher_modes {
277 AES_MODE_CBC,
278 AES_MODE_CTR,
279 AES_MODE_GCM
280};
281
282enum cryptx_aes_padding_schemes {
283 PAD_PKCS7,
284 PAD_DEFAULT = PAD_PKCS7,
287 PAD_ISO2
288};
289
290#define CRYPTX_AES128_KEYLEN 16
291#define CRYPTX_AES192_KEYLEN 24
292#define CRYPTX_AES256_KEYLEN 32
294#define CRYPTX_AES_BLOCK_SIZE 16
295#define CRYPTX_AES_IV_SIZE CRYPTX_AES_BLOCK_SIZE
296#define CRYPTX_AES_AUTHTAG_SIZE CRYPTX_AES_BLOCK_SIZE
299#define CRYPTX_AES_CBC_FLAGS(padding_mode) \
300 ((padding_mode)<<2) | AES_MODE_CBC
301
303#define CRYPTX_AES_CTR_FLAGS(nonce_len, counter_len) \
304 ((0x0f & (counter_len))<<8) | ((0x0f & (nonce_len))<<4) | AES_MODE_CTR
305
307#define CRYPTX_AES_GCM_FLAGS AES_MODE_GCM
308
310#define cryptx_aes_get_ciphertext_len(len) \
311((((len)%CRYPTX_AES_BLOCK_SIZE)==0) ? (len) + CRYPTX_AES_BLOCK_SIZE : (((len)>>4) + 1)<<4)
312
313typedef enum {
314 AES_OK,
315 AES_INVALID_ARG,
316 AES_INVALID_MSG,
317 AES_INVALID_CIPHERMODE,
318 AES_INVALID_PADDINGMODE,
319 AES_INVALID_CIPHERTEXT,
320 AES_INVALID_OPERATION
321} aes_error_t;
322
323/******************************************************
324 * @brief Initializes a stateful AES cipher context to be used for encryption or decryption.
325 * @param[in] context Pointer to an AES cipher context to initialize.
326 * @param[in] key Pointer to an 128, 192, or 256 bit key to load into the AES context.
327 * @param[in] keylen The size, in bytes, of the @b key to load.
328 * @param[in] iv Pointer to Initialization vector, a buffer equal to the block size filled with random bytes.
329 * @param[in] ivlen Length of the initalization vector. Capped at 16 bytes. Certain cipher modes have different recommendations.
330 * @param[in] flags A series of flags to configure the AES context with.
331 * Use the provided @b CRYPTX_AES_CTR_FLAGS, @b CRYPTX_AES_CBC_FLAGS, or @b CRYPTX_AES_GCM_FLAGS to pass flags.
332 * @returns An @b aes_error_t indicating the status of the AES operation.
333 * @note Contexts are not bidirectional due to being stateful. If you need to process both encryption and decryption,
334 * initialize seperate contexts for encryption and decryption. Both contexts will use the same key, but different initialization vectors.
335 * @warning It is recommended to cycle your key after encrypting 2^64 blocks of data with the same key.
336 * @warning Do not manually edit the @b ctx.mode field of the context structure.
337 * This will break the cipher configuration. If you want to change cipher modes, do so by calling @b aes_init again.
338 * @warning AES-CBC and CTR modes ensure confidentiality but do not provide message integrity verification.
339 * If you need a truly secure construction, use GCM mode or append a keyed hash (HMAC) to the encrypted message..
340 */
341aes_error_t cryptx_aes_init(struct cryptx_aes_ctx* context,
342 const void* key,
343 size_t keylen,
344 const void* iv,
345 size_t ivlen,
346 uint24_t flags);
347
348/******************************************************
349 * @brief Performs a stateful AES encryption of an arbitrary length of data.
350 * @param[in] context Pointer to an AES cipher context.
351 * @param[in] plaintext Pointer to data to encrypt.
352 * @param[in] len Length of data at @b plaintext to encrypt.
353 * @param[out] ciphertext Pointer to buffer to write encrypted data to.
354 * @returns An @b aes_error_t indicating the status of the AES operation.
355 * @note @b ciphertext should large enough to hold the encrypted message.
356 * For CBC mode, this is the smallest multiple of the blocksize that will hold the plaintext.
357 * See the @b CRYPTX_AES_CIPHERTEXT_LEN macro.
358 * For CTR and GCM modes, this is the same size as the plaintext.
359 * @note @b plaintext and @b ciphertext are aliasable.
360 * @note Encrypt is streamable, such that encrypt(msg1) + encrypt(msg2) is functionally identical to encrypt(msg1+msg2)
361 * with the exception of intervening padding in CBC mode.
362 * @note Once a context is used for encryption, it cannot be used for decryption.
363 */
364aes_error_t cryptx_aes_encrypt(const struct cryptx_aes_ctx* context,
365 const void* plaintext,
366 size_t len,
367 void* ciphertext);
368
369/******************************************************
370 * @brief Performs a stateful AES decryption of an arbitrary length of data.
371 * @param[in] context Pointer to AES cipher context.
372 * @param[in] ciphertext Pointer to data to decrypt.
373 * @param[in] len Length of data at @b ciphertext to decrypt.
374 * @param[out] plaintext Pointer to buffer to write decryped data to.
375 * @returns An @b aes_error_t indicating the status of the AES operation.
376 * @note @b plaintext and @b ciphertext are aliasable.
377 * @note Decrypt is streamable, such that decrypt(msg1) + decrypt(msg2) is functionally identical to decrypt(msg1+msg2)
378 * with the exception of intervening padding in CBC mode.
379 * @note Once a context is used for decryption, it cannot be used for encryption.
380 */
381aes_error_t cryptx_aes_decrypt(const struct cryptx_aes_ctx* context,
382 const void* ciphertext,
383 size_t len,
384 void* plaintext);
385
386/******************************************************
387 * @brief Updates the cipher context for given AAD (Additional Authenticated Data).
388 * AAD is data that is only authenticated, not encrypted.
389 * @param[in] context Pointer to an AES context.
390 * @param[in] aad Pointer to additional authenticated data segment.
391 * @param[in] aad_len Length of additional data segment.
392 * @returns An @b aes_error_t indicating the status of the AES operation.
393 * @note This function is only compatible with AES-GCM cipher mode. Attempting to
394 * use this function for any other cipher mode will return @b AES_INVALID_CIPHERMODE.
395 * @note This function can only be called between the call to @b cryptx_aes_init and the first call
396 * to @b cryptx_aes_encrypt or @b cryptx_aes_decrypt. Once encryption or decryption starts, you can
397 * no longer update AAD.
398 */
399aes_error_t cryptx_aes_update_aad(struct cryptx_aes_ctx* context,
400 const void* aad, size_t aad_len);
401
402/******************************************************
403 * @brief Returns the current authentication tag for data parsed so far.
404 * @param[in] context Pointer to an AES context
405 * @param[out] digest Pointer to a buffer to output digest to. Must be at least 16 bytes large.
406 * @returns An @b aes_error_t indicating the status of the AES operation.
407 * @note This function is only compatible with AES-GCM cipher mode. Attempting to call it for any
408 * other cipher mode will return @b AES_INVALID_CIPHERMODE.
409 * @note Calling this function terminates your use of the current AES context. This is because
410 * reuse of the IV buffer can leak the hkey used for authentication. The next stream may use the same
411 * encryption key but should have a unique IV.
412 */
413aes_error_t cryptx_aes_digest(struct cryptx_aes_ctx* context, uint8_t *digest);
414
415/******************************************************
416 * @brief Parses the specified AAD and ciphertext and then compares the output auth tag
417 * to an expected auth tag.
418 * @param[in] context Pointer to an AES context.
419 * @param[in] aad Pointer to associated data to authenticate.
420 * @param[in] aad_len Length of associated data to authenticate.
421 * @param[in] ciphertext Pointer to ciphertext to authenticate.
422 * @param[in] ciphertext_len Length of ciphertext to authenticate.
423 * @param[in] tag Pointer to expected auth tag to validate against.
424 * @returns TRUE if authentication tag matches expected, FALSE otherwise.
425 * @note operates on a dummy copy of @b *context to avoid nuking the active copy
426 * @note If this function returns FALSE, do not decrypt the message.
427 */
428
429bool cryptx_aes_verify(const struct cryptx_aes_ctx* context,
430 const void* aad, size_t aad_len,
431 const void* ciphertext, size_t ciphertext_len,
432 uint8_t *tag);
433

435//***************************************************************************************
436// RIVEST-SHAMIR-ADLEMAN (RSA) ENCRYPTION
437//***************************************************************************************
440typedef enum {
441 RSA_OK,
442 RSA_INVALID_ARG,
443 RSA_INVALID_MSG,
444 RSA_INVALID_MODULUS,
445 RSA_ENCODING_ERROR
446} rsa_error_t;
447
449#define CRYPTX_RSA_MODULUS_MAX 256
450
451/******************************************************
452 * @brief Encrypts a message using the given RSA public key.
453 * @param[in] msg Pointer to a message to encrypt using RSA.
454 * @param[in] msglen The byte length of the @b msg.
455 * @param[in] pubkey Pointer to a public key to use for encryption.
456 * @param[in] keylen The length of the public key (modulus) to encrypt with.
457 * @param[out] ciphertext Pointer a buffer to write the ciphertext to.
458 * @param[in] oaep_hash_alg The numeric ID of the hashing algorithm to use within OAEP encoding.
459 * See @b cryptx_hash_algorithms.
460 * @returns An @b rsa_error_t indicating the status of the RSA operation.
461 * @note The size of @b ciphertext and @b keylen must be equal.
462 * @note The @b msg will be encoded using OAEP before encryption.
463 * @note msg and pubkey are both treated as byte arrays.
464 * @note The public exponent is hardcoded to @b 65537.
465 */
466rsa_error_t cryptx_rsa_encrypt(const void* msg,
467 size_t msglen,
468 const void* pubkey,
469 size_t keylen,
470 void* ciphertext,
471 uint8_t oaep_hash_alg);
472
473
474//***************************************************************************************
475// ELLIPTIC CURVE DIFFIE-HELLMAN (ECDH) ENCRYPTION
476//***************************************************************************************
478// Using curve SECT233k1
479
481#define CRYPTX_ECDH_PRIVKEY_LEN 30
482
484#define CRYPTX_ECDH_PUBKEY_LEN (CRYPTX_ECDH_PRIVKEY_LEN<<1)
485#define CRYPTX_ECDH_SECRET_LEN CRYPTX_ECDH_PUBKEY_LEN
486
487#define cryptx_ecdh_generate_privkey(privkey) \
488 cryptx_csrand_fill((privkey), (CRYPTX_ECDH_PRIVKEY_LEN))
489
490typedef enum _ecdh_error {
491 ECDH_OK,
492 ECDH_INVALID_ARG,
493 ECDH_PRIVKEY_INVALID,
494 ECDH_RPUBKEY_INVALID
495} ecdh_error_t;
496
497/******************************************************
498 * @brief Generates a public key from the private key and some base point G on curve.
499 * @param[in] privkey Pointer to a randomized ECDH private key.
500 * @param[out] pubkey Pointer to buffer to write public key.
501 * @note Output public key is a point on the curve expressed as two 30-byte coordinates
502 * encoded in little endian byte order and padded with zeros (if needed). You may have to
503 * deserialize the key and then serialize it into a different format to use it with
504 * some encryption libraries.
505 * @note This function expects that @b privkey be filled with random bytes. Failure to do so
506 * may cause unexpected behavior. See @b CRYPTX_ECDH_GENERATE_PRIVKEY().
507 */
508ecdh_error_t cryptx_ecdh_publickey(const uint8_t *privkey, uint8_t *pubkey);
509
510/******************************************************
511 * @brief Computes a secret from the private key and the remote public key.
512 * @param[in] privkey Pointer to local private key.
513 * @param[in] rpubkey Pointer to remote public key.
514 * @param[out] secret Pointer to buffer to write shared secret to.
515 * @note @b secret must be at least @b CRYPTX_ECDH_SECRET_LEN bytes.
516 * @note Output secret is a point on the curve expressed as two 30-byte coordinates
517 * encoded in little endian byte order and padded with zeros if needed. You may have to
518 * deserialize the secret and then serialize it into a different format for compatibility with
519 * other encryption libraries.
520 * @note It is generally not recommended to use the computed secret as an encryption key as is.
521 * It is preferred to pass the secret to a KDF or a cryptographic primitive such as a hash function and use
522 * that output as your symmetric key.
523 */
524ecdh_error_t cryptx_ecdh_secret(const uint8_t *privkey, const uint8_t *rpubkey, uint8_t *secret);
525
526//***************************************************************************************
527// ABSTRACT SYNTAX NOTATION ONE (ASN.1) DECODING
528//***************************************************************************************
531enum CRYPTX_ASN1_TAGS {
532 ASN1_RESVD = 0,
533 ASN1_BOOLEAN,
534 ASN1_INTEGER,
535 ASN1_BITSTRING,
536 ASN1_OCTETSTRING,
537 ASN1_NULL,
538 ASN1_OBJECTID,
539 ASN1_OBJECTDESC,
540 ASN1_INSTANCE,
541 ASN1_REAL,
542 ASN1_ENUMERATED,
543 ASN1_EMBEDDEDPDV,
544 ASN1_UTF8STRING,
545 ASN1_RELATIVEOID,
546 ASN1_SEQUENCE = 16,
547 ASN1_SET,
548 ASN1_NUMERICSTRING,
549 ASN1_PRINTABLESTRING,
550 ASN1_TELETEXSTRING,
551 ASN1_VIDEOTEXSTRING,
552 ASN1_IA5STRING,
553 ASN1_UTCTIME,
554 ASN1_GENERALIZEDTIME,
555 ASN1_GRAPHICSTRING,
556 ASN1_VISIBLESTRING,
557 ASN1_GENERALSTRING,
558 ASN1_UNIVERSALSTRING,
559 ASN1_CHARSTRING,
560 ASN1_BMPSTRING
561};
562
563enum CRYPTX_ASN1_CLASSES {
564 ASN1_UNIVERSAL,
565 ASN1_APPLICATION,
566 ASN1_CONTEXTSPEC,
567 ASN1_PRIVATE
568};
569
570enum CRYPTX_ASN1_FORMS {
571 ASN1_PRIMITIVE,
572 ASN1_CONSTRUCTED,
573};
574
576#define cryptx_asn1_get_tag(tag) ((tag) & 0b111111)
578#define cryptx_asn1_get_class(tag) (((tag)>>6) & 0b11)
580#define cryptx_asn1_get_form(tag) (((tag)>>5) & 1)
581
582typedef enum {
583 ASN1_OK,
584 ASN1_END_OF_FILE,
585 ASN1_INVALID_ARG,
586 ASN1_LEN_OVERFLOW,
587} asn1_error_t;
588
589/******************************************************
590 * @brief Decodes the ASN.1 data at the given address. Seeks to an element from the front of the data.
591 * @param data_start Pointer to a block of ASN.1-encoded data.
592 * @param data_len Length of ASN.1-encoded block.
593 * @param seek_to Number of ASN.1 elements to skip before returning one.
594 * @param element_tag Masked tag value of the returned element.
595 * @param element_len Length of the returned element.
596 * @param element_data Pointer to the data of the returned element.
597 * @returns An @b asn1_error_t indicating the status of the operation.
598 * @note @b ASN1_END_OF_FILE will be returned if @b seek_to is invalid.
599 * @note ASN.1 is a tree structure. You can use the @b element_data and @b element_len parameters
600 * returned by this function to iterate further up the tree. To see if an element is of a type for which this is
601 * valid, check the return value of @b CRYPTX_ASN1_FORM(element_tag).
602 * @note NULL may be passed for @b element_tag, @b element_len, and/or @b element_data if you do not
603 * need to return that particular bit of information.
604 */
605asn1_error_t cryptx_asn1_decode(
606 void *data_start,
607 size_t data_len,
608 uint8_t seek_to,
609 uint8_t *element_tag,
610 size_t *element_len,
611 uint8_t **element_data);
612
613
614//***************************************************************************************
615// BASE64 DECODING
616//***************************************************************************************
619#define cryptx_base64_get_encoded_len(len) ((len) * 4 / 3)
620#define cryptx_base64_get_decoded_len(len) ((len) * 3 / 4)
621
622/******************************************************
623 * @brief Converts an octet-encoded byte stream into a sextet-encoded byte stream.
624 * @param dest Pointer to output sextet-encoded data stream.
625 * @param src Pointer to input octet-encoded data stream.
626 * @param len Length of octet-encoded data stream.
627 * @note @b dest should be at least @b len \* 4 / 3 bytes large.
628 * @returns Length of output sextet.
629 */
630size_t cryptx_base64_encode(void *dest, const void *src, size_t len);
631
632/******************************************************
633 * @brief Converts a sextet-encoded byte stream into a octet-encoded byte stream.
634 * @param dest Pointer to output octet-encoded data stream.
635 * @param src Pointer to input sextet-encoded data stream.
636 * @param len Length of sextet-encoded data stream.
637 * @note @b dest should be at least @b len \* 3 / 4 bytes large.
638 * @returns Length of output octet.
639 */
640size_t cryptx_base64_decode(void *dest, const void *src, size_t len);
